Certainly! Here's an outline for a series of eLearning courses on Ruby on Rails, organized into smaller courses with at least two modules each. Each course is designed to be concise, under two hours, and covers a specific set of skills related to Ruby on Rails.

```html
<div id="data">
  <div class="course">
    <h3>Course 1: Introduction to Ruby on Rails</h3>
    <section class="module">
      <strong>Module 1: Basic Programming Concepts</strong>
      <li>Understanding of variables, data types, and operators</li>
      <li>Familiarity with conditional statements (if, else) and loops</li>
    </section>
    <section class="module">
      <strong>Module 2: Getting Started with Ruby</strong>
      <li>Installing Ruby and a code editor</li>
      <li>Basic syntax and data structures in Ruby</li>
    </section>
  </div>

  <div class="course">
    <h3>Course 2: Building Your First Rails App</h3>
    <section class="module">
      <strong>Module 1: Introduction to Rails</strong>
      <li>Installing Ruby on Rails</li>
      <li>Creating a new Rails project</li>
    </section>
    <section class="module">
      <strong>Module 2: Model-View-Controller (MVC) Architecture</strong>
      <li>Understanding the MVC pattern</li>
      <li>Creating models, views, and controllers</li>
    </section>
  </div>

  <div class="course">
    <h3>Course 3: Working with Databases in Rails</h3>
    <section class="module">
      <strong>Module 1: Database Management with ActiveRecord</strong>
      <li>Setting up a database in Rails</li>
      <li>Creating and migrating database tables</li>
    </section>
    <section class="module">
      <strong>Module 2: Routing and URLs</strong>
      <li>Defining routes in Rails</li>
      <li>Creating user-friendly URLs</li>
    </section>
  </div>

  <div class="course">
    <h3>Course 4: Building Dynamic Views</h3>
    <section class="module">
      <strong>Module 1: Views and Templates</strong>
      <li>Creating views using ERB (Embedded Ruby)</li>
      <li>Working with layouts and partials</li>
    </section>
    <section class="module">
      <strong>Module 2: Controllers and Actions</strong>
      <li>Defining controller actions</li>
      <li>Handling user input and parameters</li>
    </section>
  </div>

  <div class="course">
    <h3>Course 5: User Authentication and Authorization</h3>
    <section class="module">
      <strong>Module 1: Authentication with Devise</strong>
      <li>Implementing user authentication with Devise</li>
      <li>Setting up user roles and permissions</li>
    </section>
    <section class="module">
      <strong>Module 2: Securing Routes and Actions</strong>
      <li>Securing routes and actions based on user roles</li>
    </section>
  </div>

  <div class="course">
    <h3>Course 6: Testing and Deployment</h3>
    <section class="module">
      <strong>Module 1: Testing in Rails</strong>
      <li>Writing unit tests and integration tests</li>
      <li>Using tools like RSpec and Capybara</li>
    </section>
    <section class="module">
      <strong>Module 2: Deployment and Hosting</strong>
      <li>Deploying a Rails application to a web server (e.g., Heroku)</li>
      <li>Managing server and application configurations</li>
    </section>
  </div>

  <div class="course">
    <h3>Course 7: Advanced Topics in Ruby on Rails</h3>
    <section class="module">
      <strong>Module 1: Performance Optimization</strong>
      <li>Identifying and optimizing database queries</li>
      <li>Caching strategies in Rails</li>
    </section>
    <section class="module">
      <strong>Module 2: Working with APIs</strong>
      <li>Consuming external APIs in Rails applications</li>
      <li>Building APIs using Rails for other applications to use</li>
    </section>
  </div>

  <div class="course">
    <h3>Course 8: Continuing Your Rails Journey</h3>
    <section class="module">
      <strong>Module 1: Background Jobs and Asynchronous Processing</strong>
      <li>Implementing background jobs in Rails</li>
    </section>
    <section class="module">
      <strong>Module 2: Staying Updated and Exploring Advanced Topics</strong>
      <li>Participating in the Rails community and forums</li>
      <li>Exploring advanced topics like WebSockets and GraphQL</li>
    </section>
  </div>
</div>
```

Each course is divided into two modules to ensure a manageable pace for high school-level students. These courses cover the essential skills needed to master Ruby on Rails in a structured and concise manner.
